{{DEFAULTSORT:Timeline Of European Exploration}} [[Category:Exploration|T]] [[Category:Historical timelines|European exploration]] [[Category:Historical eras]] [[Category:Age of Discovery|.]] [[Category:History of Europe]] [[Category:History of geography]] [[Category:Maritime history]] [[Category:Modern history timelines|European exploration]]<!--only 19th-20th century-->

revision.comment: /* top */ list grammar
revision.text:
USBL ('''ultra-short baseline''', also sometimes known as '''SSBL''' for super short base line) is a [[Underwater Acoustic Positioning System|method of underwater acoustic positioning]]. A complete USBL system consists of a [[transceiver]], which is mounted on a pole under a ship, and a [[Transponder|transponder or responder]] on the seafloor, on a [[towfish]], or on an [[Remotely operated underwater vehicle|ROV]]. A computer, or "topside unit", is used to calculate a position from the ranges and bearings measured by the transceiver.
An [[Acoustics|acoustic]] pulse is transmitted by the transceiver and detected by the subsea transponder, which replies with its own acoustic pulse. This return pulse is detected by the shipboard transceiver. The time from the transmission of the initial acoustic pulse until the reply is detected is measured by the USBL system and is converted into a range.
To calculate a subsea position, the USBL calculates both a range and an angle from the transceiver to the [[subsea]] beacon. Angles are measured by the transceiver, which contains an array of [[transducers]]. The transceiver head normally contains three or more transducers separated by a baseline of 10 cm or less. A method called “[[Phase difference|phase-differencing]]” within this [[Microphone array|transducer array]] is used to calculate the direction to the subsea transponder.
USBLs have also begun to find use in "inverted" (iUSBL) configurations, with the transceiver mounted on an [[autonomous underwater vehicle]], and the transponder on the target. In this case, the "topside" processing happens inside the vehicle to allow it to locate the transponder for applications such as [[automatic docking]] and [[Tracking system|target tracking]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.hydro-international.com/productsurvey/id13-UltraShort_Baseline_Systems.html Product Survey USBL Systems] Hydro International, May 2008.
===Manufacturers=== * [http://www.ixblue.com/products/4th-generation-gaps IXBLUE - GAPS pre-calibrated Ultra-Short BaseLine - ] * [http://www.ixblue.com/products/posidonia IXBLUE - POSIDONIA - Ultra-deep & long range Ultra-Short Baseline - ] * [http://www.nautronix.com/product.php?id=nasdrill-usbl Nautronix USBL] * [http://www.appliedacoustics.com/Products_Easy.aspx?content=system EASYTRAK USBL Applied Acoustics] * [http://www.link-quest.com/html/intro2.htm TrackLink USBL - LinkQuest] * [http://www.tritech.co.uk/product/usbl-tracking-system-micronnav Tritech International Ltd] * [http://sonardyne.com/products/positioning/usbl-all-systems.html Sonardyne Ranger 2 and Scout USBLs] * [http://www.km.kongsberg.com/ks/web/nokbg0240.nsf/AllWeb/FF57C18363FAD917C1256A7E002B9F2F?OpenDocument Kongsberg Acoustic Positioning] * [http://www.evologics.de/en/products/USBL/index.html EvoLogics USBL Modems]
{{hydroacoustics}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = what3words | logo = what3words logo.png | logo_size = | logo_alt = What3words Company Logo | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = | founded = {{start date and age|2013}} | founders ={{Unbulleted list|Chris Sheldrick|[[Jack Waley-Cohen]]|Mohan Ganesalingam|Michael Dent}} <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location = [[Westbourne Studios]] | hq_location_city = London | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | website = {{URL|what3words.com}} }} '''what3words''' is a [[geocoding]] system for the communication of locations with a resolution of three metres. What3words encodes [[geographic coordinates]] into three dictionary words. For example, the torch of the [[Statue of Liberty]] is located at "toned.melt.ship". This differs from most other location encoding systems in that it displays three words rather than long strings of numbers or letters. What3words has a website, apps for iOS and Android, and an [[API]] that enables bidirectional conversion of what3words address and latitude/longitude coordinates. As the system relies on a fixed algorithm, not a large database of every location on earth, it works on devices with limited storage and no internet connection, and the encoding is permanently fixed and unchangeable.
==History== Founded by Chris Sheldrick, [[Jack Waley-Cohen]], Mohan Ganesalingam, and Michael Dent, what3words launched in July 2013.<ref name="w3w-launch">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2013/07/02/what3words_n_3532121.html|title='What3Words' Wants To Replace Postcodes With Words – For The Entire Globe|date=2 Jul 2013}}</ref><ref name="w3w-launch-2">{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/08/what3words/|title=Location-Pinpointing Startup what3words Sells 10,000+ OneWord Map-Pins In First Week|date=8 Jul 2016}}</ref><ref name="w3w-team">{{cite web|url=http://what3words.com/team/|title=what3words team|access-date=9 Dec 2016}}</ref> Sheldrick and Ganesalingam originally conceived the idea after Sheldrick struggled to get equipment and bands to event locations on time due to inadequate addressing while working as a concert organizer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://magenta.as/this-app-gives-even-the-most-remote-spots-on-the-planet-an-address-4f09f4bca94e|title=This App Gives Even the Most Remote Spots on the Planet an Address}}</ref> The company was incorporated on March 5, 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/08430008|title=what3words limited}}</ref> and a patent application for the core technology filed on April 19, 2013.<ref name="w3w-patent">{{cite web|url=https://patentscope.wipo.int/search/en/detail.jsf?docId=WO2014170646|title=WO2014170646 A METHOD AND APPARATUS FOR IDENTIFYING AND COMMUNICATING LOCATIONS}}</ref>
In November 2013, what3words raised $500,000 of seed funding,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vcpost.com/articles/17534/20131106/startup-what3words-gets-usd-500-000-seed-round.htm|title=Startup what3words gets USD 500,000 in seed round|work=Venture Capital Post}}</ref> and in March 2014 the company raised a second seed round of $1,000,000.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/03/20/what3words-1m/|title=Location Pinpointing Startup what3words Adds $1M More To Its Seed To Flog More Map Labels|publisher=AOL|work=TechCrunch}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://startups.co.uk/what3words-closes-1m-to-expand-alternative-to-postcodes-mapping-service/|title=what3words closes $1m to expand ‘alternative to postcodes’ mapping service|work=Startups.co.uk: Starting a business advice and business ideas}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vcpost.com/articles/22723/20140320/what3words-adds-1m-more-to-seed-round.htm|title=What3words adds $1M more to seed round|work=Venture Capital Post}}</ref> On November 3, 2015, what3words closed a $3.5 million [[Series A round|Series A]] funding round led by [[Intel Capital]], with [[Li Ka-shing]]'s [[Horizons Ventures]] participating.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/11/03/what3words-series-a/|title=what3words Gets $3.5M Led by Intel Capital To Simplify Location Sharing|publisher=}}</ref> On June 29, 2016, what3words closed a $8.5 million Series B round led by [[Aramex]].<ref name="techcrunch.com">{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/06/29/addressing-platform-what3words-closes-8-5m-series-b-led-by-logistics-firm-aramex/|title=Addressing platform what3words closes $8.5M Series B led by logistics firm Aramex|publisher=}}</ref><!--?--> On January 10, 2018, [[Mercedes-Benz]] bought approximately 10% of the company and announced what3words support in future versions of the Mercedes-Benz User Experience (MBUX) infotainment and navigation system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2018/01/11/daimler-mercedes-what3words/|title=Why Daimler Invested in a Startup That Has Labeled the World With Unique Three-Word Addresses|publisher=}}</ref> The A-Class, launched in May 2018, became the first vehicle in the world with what3words on board.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/wirtschaft/bilanz/article175180978/What3words-Diese-Ortungssoftware-gibt-es-bald-serienmaessig-in-Daimlers-A-Klasse.html|title=What3words: Diese Ortungssoftware gibt es bald serienmäßig in Daimlers A-Klasse|first=Michael|last=Brecht|date=5 April 2018|publisher=|via=www.welt.de}}</ref>
In March 2016, the company announced that Colorado-based [[Steve Coast]], founder of [[OpenStreetMap]], joined the team as Chief Evangelist, charged with developing and strengthening partnerships in North America.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wallace |first1=Anthony |title=Founder of OpenStreetMap joins what3words |url=https://www.spatialsource.com.au/latest-news/founder-of-openstreetmap-joins-what3words |website=Spatial Source |accessdate=27 July 2018 |date=30 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=what3words hires Steve Coast, founder of OpenStreetMap {{!}} GeoConnexion |url=https://www.geoconnexion.com/news/what3words-hires-steve-coast-founder-of-openstreetmap |website=www.geoconnexion.com |accessdate=27 July 2018 |language=en}}</ref> Coast has since moved on.
==Design principles== what3words uses a grid of the world made up of 57 trillion squares of 3 metres by 3 metres. Each square has been given a three-word English address. What3words has named the world's landmass with three words in various other languages. {{As of|2016|12}}, what3words addresses (as well as web and iOS app user interface) are available in Arabic, English, Finnish, French, German, Italian, Mongolian, Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish, and Turkish; the iOS app also supports Swahili. What3words launched 12 more languages at the start of 2018: Indonesian, Zulu, Japanese, Korean, and Hindi.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/rebeccafeng/2016/06/11/new-company-aims-to-give-billions-of-people-one-thing-they-dont-have-an-address/|title=Startup What3words Aims To Give Billions Of People One Thing They Don't Have: An Address|first=Rebecca|last=Feng|publisher=}}</ref> The company has also mentioned Chinese and various languages of Pakistan, including Urdu and Farsi.<ref name="w3w-about">{{cite web|url=http://w3w.co/about|title=About |publisher=what3words}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cityam.com/249560/what3words-co-founder-chris-sheldrick-explains-his-company|title=Meet What3Words: The London startup changing our understanding of location|first=Harriet|last=Green|date=19 September 2016|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.zawya.com/mena/en/story/GN_06072016_070713/|title=Mapping the world in three words|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/startups-try-to-put-remote-e-commerce-customers-on-the-map-1468603499|title=Startups Try to Put Remote E-Commerce Customers on the Map|first=Erica E.|last=Phillips|date=15 July 2016|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref>
Each what3words language uses a wordlist of 25,000 words (40,000 in English, as it covers the sea as well as land). The lists go through multiple automated and human processes before being sorted by an algorithm that takes into account word length, distinctiveness, frequency, and ease of spelling and pronunciation. [[Homophones]] and [[variant spellings]] are treated to minimize any potential for confusion, and offensive words are removed.<ref name="w3w-about"/>
The what3words algorithm actively shuffles similar-sounding three-word combinations around the world to enable both human and automated error-checking. The result is that if a three-word combination is entered slightly incorrectly and the result is still a valid what3words reference, the location will usually be so far away from the user's intended area that it will be immediately obvious to both a user and an intelligent error-checking system.<ref name="w3w-about"/>
The what3words system uses a proprietary [[algorithm]] in combination with a limited database, meaning that the core technology is contained within a file around 10 MB in size. The database is used to assign more memorable words to locations in urban areas.<ref name="w3w-patent"/> what3words originally sold "OneWord" addresses, which were stored in a database for a yearly fee,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/07/08/what3words/|title=Location-Pinpointing Startup what3words Sells 10,000+ OneWord Map-Pins In First Week|date=8 Jul 2013|website=TechCrunch|last=Lomas|first=Natasha}}</ref> but this feature has been canceled.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/what3words/status/594070034625986561|title=what3words on Twitter: "we did charge for that functionality but no longer offer it."|date=1 May 2015}}</ref>
The main claimed advantages of what3words are memorability, error-detection, unambiguous nature of words for most everyday and non-technical uses and voice input.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/life/the-wiki-man/9348462/the-best-navigation-idea-ive-seen-since-the-tube-map/|title=The best navigation idea I've seen since the Tube map|publisher=''[[The Spectator]]''|date=25 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=A comparison of immediate memory span for digits, letters, and words |last=Crannell |first=C. W. |last2=Parrish |first2=J. M. |journal=The Journal of Psychology: Interdisciplinary and Applied |url=http://psycnet.apa.org/psycinfo/1959-09803-001 |volume=44 |date=1957 |pages=319–327}}</ref>
==Critiques == Supporters of open standards denounce the what3words system for being controlled by a private business and the software for being copyrighted and thus not freely usable. The fact that similar addresses are purposely far away from each other is also seen by some as a disadvantage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/style/2016/06/30/what-words-quite-find/143z4Pnov2aP7gmBzWuxEK/story.html|title=What3Words is quite a find|publisher=The Boston Globe|date=1 Jul 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.ldodds.com/2016/06/14/what-3-words-jog-on-mate/|title=What 3 Words? Jog on mate!|first=Leigh|last=Dodds|date=14 Jun 2016}}</ref><ref name="osmwikiw3w">{{Cite web|url=https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/w/index.php?title=What3words&oldid=1421526|title=What3words|publisher=OpenStreetMap wiki|date=20 Jan 2017}}</ref>
==Users==
Automotive * [[Mercedes-Benz]] – in-car voice navigation system<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/peterlyon/2017/09/14/just-3-words-will-pinpoint-your-location-in-stunning-new-mapping-system-used-by-mercedes/#34e3f0dc6e00|title=You Have A New 3 Word Address: Find It At What3words|first=Peter|last=Lyon|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Land Rover]] – off-road driving<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.directionsmag.com/pressrelease/4870|title=what3words Extends Middle East Presence with the Launch of Addressing System in Arabic|website=www.directionsmag.com}}</ref> * [[Mongol Rally]] – addressing electric car charging points between the UK and Mongolia <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wheels24.co.za/Motorsport/2017-mongol-rally-nissans-electric-leaf-to-take-on-16-000km-race-20170428|title=2017 Mongol Rally: Nissan's electric Leaf to take on 16 000km race|publisher=}}</ref>
Aid and humanitarian * [[Red Cross]] – Disaster relief<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diginomica.com/2017/07/21/technology-social-good-what3words-international-relief-efforts/|title=Technology for social good - what3words and international relief efforts - diginomica government|date=21 July 2017|publisher=}}</ref> * [[United Nations]] – disaster and humanitarian reporting app UN-ASIGN<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ee.co.za/article/un-disaster-app-includes-three-word-addresses.html|title=UN disaster app includes three word addresses|work=EE Publishers}}</ref>
Mobility * [[Quiqup]] – on-demand logistics in London, UK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.directcommercemagazine.com/news/fulfilment-delivery/quiqup-shaves-30-per-cent-off-delivery-time-with-3-word-addresses|title=Quiqup shaves 30 per cent off delivery time with 3 word addresses|website=www.directcommercemagazine.com}}</ref>
Delivery & logistics *[[Aramex]] – global delivery and logistics <ref name="techcrunch.com"/> *[[Ivory Coast]] uses this system for mail deliveries.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-38262877 |title=Ivory Coast post office adopts three-word system |publisher=BBC |date=2016-12-09}}</ref> *[[Mongol Post]] adopted what3words for postal deliveries throughout the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mongol Post adopts what3words as national addressing system|url=http://mongolpost.mn/more/156|publisher=Mongol Post|accessdate=19 June 2016|date=23 May 2016}}</ref> *[[airbnb]] - directing vacation visitors to nomad reindeer herder host's camp location<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/11/19/airbnb-is-using-what3words-to-list-stays-with-mongolian-nomads/|title=Airbnb is using what3words to list stays with Mongolian nomads|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2018-11-21|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=what3words|title=The Reindeer Tribe Airbnb {{!}} Airbnb and what3words|date=2018-11-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cUBo3zEE_c4|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>
Festivals and events *[[Farnborough International Airshow]] <ref>https://www.geospatialworld.net/news-posts/earth-i-what3words-keep-an-eye-on-farnborough-international-airshow-from-above/</ref> *[[Glastonbury Festival]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/healthcare-network/2016/jun/21/injured-glastonbury-app-what-3-words|title=Injured at Glastonbury? Three little words will help medics find you|first=S. A.|last=Mathieson|date=21 June 2016|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
Asset management *[[Pollinate]] – energy solar lighting installation in the slums of India *[[Videre]] – solar lighting installations in Botswana
==Awards== *Grand Prix for Innovation at the [[Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/special-report-cannes-lions/what3words-innovation-grand-prix-cannes/299245/|title=What3Words Innovation Grand Prix Cannes – Special: Cannes Lions – Advertising Age|first=Ann-Christine|last=Diaz|date=26 June 2015|work=adage.com}}</ref> * [[The Tech Awards]] [[John Sobrato|Sobrato Organization]] Economic Development Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/business/ci_29110330/tech-awards-honor-an-array-laureates|title=San Jose: Tech awards honor an array of laureates|date=12 November 2015|publisher=}}</ref> * [[D&AD]] Black Pencil<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dandad.org/awards/professional/2016/creativity-for-good-white-pencil/25060/the-world-addressed/|title=The World Addressed - what3words - what3words - D&AD Awards 2016 Pencil Winner - Service Innovations - D&AD|website=www.dandad.org}}</ref> * [[Financial Times|FT]]/[[International Finance Corporation|IFC]] Transformational Business Awards commendation for Achievement in Transformational Technology<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/45442848@N05/27543176306/in/album-72157666923588814/|title=FT/IFC Transformational Business Awards 2016|publisher=}}</ref> * [[KPMG]] Best British Mobile Startup<ref>https://home.kpmg.com/uk/en/home/media/press-releases/2016/02/what3words-crowned-best-british-mobile-startup-2016-at-mwc.html</ref> * [[PWC]] Great Innovation Challenge Winner<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pwc.co.uk/who-we-are/great-innovation-competition-2016.html|title=About us|first=|last=PricewaterhouseCoopers|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Accenture]] Consumer Innovation Award<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newsroom.accenture.com/news/accenture-consumer-innovation-award-winners-announced.htm|title=Accenture Consumer Innovation Award Winners Announced - Accenture Newsroom|website=newsroom.accenture.com}}</ref> * [[British Telecommunications Group plc|BT]] Tech for Good Award<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tech4goodawards.com/finalist/what3words/|title=what3words - BT Ingenious Award - Global Innovation|publisher=}}</ref> * [[INDEX: Design to Improve Life|INDEX Awards]] Design to Improve Life<ref>{{cite web|url=https://designtoimprovelife.dk/what3words-2017-home-winner//|title=WHAT3WORDS: 2017 HOME WINNER - INDEX: Design to Improve Life®|date=1 September 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
== Parodies ==
A number of parody sites have been created to satirize what3word's proprietary nature, including:
* [http://what2numbers.org/ What2Numbers] – uses [[WGS84 coordinates]] * [http://www.what3fucks.com/ What3Fucks] – uses [[swear word]]s * [http://what3ducks.com what3ducks] – uses [[duck]]s * [http://what3emojis.com/ What3Emojis] - uses [[emoji]]s * [http://www.what3pokemon.com/ What 3 Pokemon] - uses [[Pokemon]] characters * [http://www.what3ikea.com/ What 3 Ikea] * [http://www.what3goshdarnits.com/ What 3 Gosh Darnits] - euphemized version of What 3 Fucks
==Competitors==
Alphanumeric competitors include: * [[Open Location Code]] (2014) * [http://www.makaney.net/ Makaney Code] (2011) * [[Geohash]] (2008) * [[MapCode]] (2008) * [[Universal Transverse Mercator coordinate system]] * [[Maidenhead_Locator_System]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.what3words.com}} * Mobile apps - [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/what3words/id657878530?mt=8 iOS] | [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.what3words.android Android] {{Geocoding-systems}}
